questions.text: The dead body shows the following finding as in image . What is this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Smothering:

Smothering is characterized by the presence of bruises around the perioral region and nail abrasions around the lips and nose. Petechial hemorrhages are also commonly observed in smothering cases. This form of asphyxia occurs when an object or material covers the nose and mouth, obstructing the airways and preventing breathing.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hanging:

In hanging cases, there is typically a ligature mark around the neck, and the pattern of petechiae is usually more prominent in the eyes and face rather than the perioral region. There are often no specific bruises around the lips or nail abrasions.

Option B - Throttling:

Throttling involves a deep bruise or contusion around the neck, commonly seen as a result of manual compression. This would not typically present with bruises specifically around the perioral region or nail abrasions.

Option C - Choking:

Choking usually does not result in significant external trauma or bruising around the perioral area. Instead, it is characterized by signs of airway obstruction without specific bruises around the lips or petechial hemorrhages.

questions.text: What is the Zasko phenomenon?

choices.text: Seepage of blood from wounds around time of death
Gaping of wound along tension lines

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Tendon reflex occurring after death:

Explanation:

  • The Zasko phenomenon refers to the persistence of certain tendon reflexes for a short period after death.
  • It occurs due to residual neuromuscular excitability before complete cessation of neuronal activity and before rigor mortis sets in.
  • These reflexes can occasionally be elicited by tapping tendons soon after death and may be used in early postmortem examinations to help estimate the time since death.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Seepage of blood from wounds is a perimortem finding but is not the Zasko phenomenon.

Option C - Clotting of blood after death is a normal postmortem change, not related to reflexes.

Option D - Gaping of wounds along tension lines is due to skin elasticity and is unrelated to postmortem reflex activity.

questions.text: The postmortem change seen in the image below corresponds to which of the following:
questions.solution:
Correct Ans: A

  • Marbling: Marbling refers to the mottled appearance of blood vessels seen on the surface of the skin or internal organs due to the formation of blood clots after death. This change occurs as a result of the breakdown of blood cells and the settling of blood components. Marbling is commonly observed in the early stages of decomposition.

Incorrect option: 

Option B. Algor mortis: Algor mortis refers to the cooling of the body after death. It is the gradual loss of body heat until the body reaches the ambient temperature. It is not directly associated with any visual changes on the body.

Option C. Rigor mortis: Rigor mortis is the stiffening of the muscles after death due to the coagulation of muscle proteins. It is a temporary condition that usually starts within a few hours after death and resolves after 24 to 48 hours.

Option D. Post mortem lividity: Post mortem lividity, also known as livor mortis, is the pooling or settling of blood in the dependent parts of the body after death. It results in a purplish or bluish discoloration of the skin in the lower areas due to gravity.

questions.text: In a dead body, bloating of face, tongue protrusions were noted along with the findings in the image. Identify the phenomenon:
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Putrefaction

  • Various signs and changes are observed during putrefaction, including bloating of the face and other body parts, as well as tongue protrusion.

 

Putrefaction

  • Putrefaction is driven by bacterial activity, resulting in tissue breakdown and gas production.

 

Characteristics of Putrefaction:

  • Bacterial Involvement: Primarily caused by Clostridium perfringens.
  • Lytic Enzyme: The main enzyme involved is lecithinase, which breaks down cell membranes.

 

Stages of Putrefaction:

  1. Color Change:
    • The first internal change is reddish-brown discoloration of the aortic intima.
    • The first external change is green discoloration in the right iliac fossa due to the breakdown of hemoglobin.
  2. Mechanism of Color Change:
    • Hydrogen Sulfide Production: Bacteria produce hydrogen sulfide, which forms a green compound with hemoglobin.
    • The cecum is the primary site of discoloration due to high bacterial activity.
  3. Gas Formation:
    • Gas production leads to bloating, with gases like carbon dioxide, methane, and hydrogen sulfide.
  4. Liquefaction of Tissue:
    • Tissues become liquefied, losing structural integrity, contributing to the characteristic odor of decomposition.

 

Timing of Discoloration:

  • Discoloration begins within 12-18 hours in summer and 1-2 days in winter, influenced by temperature and bacterial activity.

 

Electrocution & Crocodile burns (Option A & B) refers to the injury or death caused by an electric shock. It does not specifically result in bloating of the face, tongue protrusion, or putrefaction. Electrocution-related findings would typically involve specific burn patterns or injury marks associated with the electrical source. Crocodile burns are seen in high voltage electric burns.

Scalds (Option C) are burns caused by contact with hot liquids or steam. Changes, such as blisters and skin peeling are seen. Scalds are acute injuries and do not involve postmortem processes

Incorrect Options:

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the post-mortem change shown in the image given below?

choices.text: Seen within first 12 hours of death
It occurs due to the accumulation of deoxygenated blood
It results due to bacterial activity
It is seen in case of lightning

questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) It results from bacterial activity

 

Explanation:

The branching pattern along the blood vessels is typical of marbling, which occurs due to bacterial (Clostridium welchii) decomposition of hemoglobin into sulfmethemoglobin. This phenomenon usually appears 24 hours after death.

 

Marbling

Definition

Refers to a characteristic pattern in the skin caused by decomposition.

Mechanism

After death, bacteria (Option C) spread through blood vessels, decomposing hemoglobin into sulfmethemoglobin (Option B), which causes greenish or reddish-brown staining of the vessel walls.

Pattern

Marbled pattern follows a linear branching pattern, resembling tree branches, which initially appears red and later transitions to a greenish hue.

Onset and Timing
  • Begins to develop 24 hours after death.
  • Becomes prominent by 36-48 hours.

Color Changes Over Time

Skin’s reddish-green marbling may turn dark green or nearly black within 3 to 4 days.

Areas of Marbling

Shoulders, roots of the limbs, thighs, sides of the abdomen, chest, and neck.

Medicolegal Importance

Helps in determining the time since death

Image

questions.text: The phenomenon shown below is typically seen in the case of ?

choices.text: Case of suspension or hanging more than 72 hours
Case of immersion in water for 36 hours
Case of colliquative liquefaction due to immersion in hot water

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Case of immersion in water for 36 hours

  • Immersion in water for an extended period can lead to specific postmortem changes.
  • These changes include maceration of the skin, separation of the epidermis, and swelling due to water absorption.Additionally, there may be a softening and detachment of the skin, known as a "washerwoman's hands" or "glove-like" appearance.
  • Other features that can be observed include skin slippage, wrinkling, and a pale appearance.

Condition

Cause

Symptoms

Treatment
  • Immersion Syndrome (Trench/Immersion Foot/Hand)
  • Prolonged exposure to severe cold (<10ºC) and dampness (common in warfare, trenches, or sea immersion)
  • Affects extremities (feet, hands)
  • Cold, numbness, burning, cyanosis
  • Air drying, protecting extremities from trauma and infection, gradual rewarming by air exposure at room temperature (avoid heat, massaging, or moistening the skin)

Case of torture phalanges (Option A) Torture can cause various injuries and damage to the phalanges, such as fractures, dislocations, or soft tissue injuries. Torture-related injuries would have different characteristics and patterns than those resulting from water immersion.

Case of suspension or hanging more than 72 hours (Option B) Prolonged suspension or hanging can lead to characteristic postmortem changes, such as livor mortis (postmortem lividity), rigor mortis (stiffening of the body), and changes in the neck due to ligature marks or fractures.

Case of colliquative liquefaction due to immersion in hot water (Option D) refers to the process of tissue breakdown and liquefaction that occurs in certain conditions, such as prolonged immersion in warm or hot water.

questions.text: Identify the following post mortem change:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Suggillation

 

Explanation:

Livor Mortis

Other Names

Postmortem staining, subcutaneous hypostasis, cadaveric lividity, suggillation, cogitation, vibices, and darkening of death.

Definition

Bluish or purplish-red discoloration caused by the gravitational settling of blood in the toneless capillaries and venules of the dependent parts of the dead body.

Site

Superficial layers of the dermis

Mechanism

Blood in capillaries and venules → Stagnates and sinks in dependent parts due to gravity → Bluish purple discoloration due to deoxy hemoglobin.

Begins

0.5 - 1 hour

Fully Developed

Within 4 hours

Fixation of Livor Mortis

Typically, within 6-12 hours

Confirmation of Fixation

Apply thumb pressure against the skin for a few seconds → Blanching → Livor mortis not fixed.

Primary Lividity

Occurs as lividity reaches maximum intensity between 6 to 12 hours after death.

Secondary Lividity

Shifting of lividity can occur if the body is moved within a few hours after death.

Duration of Persistence

Staining persists until putrefaction begins.

Distribution

Depends on position of the body:

Supine

Appears on the back of neck, entire back, flanks, except areas under pressure (contact pallor).

Prone

Appears on the front part of the body.

Side

Appears on the dependent side.

Head downwards

Appears as a blackened face and neck.

Vertical suspension

Appears on legs and hands (glove and stocking appearance) and external genitalia.

Drowning

Appears on the face, upper chest, hands, lower arms, feet, and calves.

Livor Mortis Absent

  • Excessive blood loss
  • Severe anemia
  • Death from wasting diseases
  • Lobar pneumonia

Medicolegal Importance
  • Helps estimate time of death.
  • Indicates body posture at death.
  • Indicates if the body was moved post-death.
  • Distribution may indicate the cause of death.

Image

Tattooing (Option A) refers to the deposition of gunpowder particles on the skin when fired from a close distance. It creates small punctate marks around the entrance wound and is associated with firearm injuries, not a postmortem change.

 

Putrefaction (Option C) refers to the decomposition of the body caused by bacterial activity, leading to the breakdown of tissues, gas formation, color changes, and a characteristic odor. This process occurs after death but is not the immediate postmortem change indicated in the question.

 

Decomposition (Option D) occurs through autolysis (self-digestion by body enzymes) and putrefaction (bacterial breakdown, primarily by Clostridium perfringens). Putrefaction involves lecithinase breaking down cell membranes, gas formation, and color changes like green discoloration. Timing of decomposition varies with temperature, starting within 12-18 hours in summer.

questions.text: In an autopsy of suspected poisoning, which organ, along with the stomach, part of the intestine, and liver, is preserved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Kidney

In the context of a suspected poisoning autopsy, the kidney, along with the stomach, part of the intestine, and liver, is preserved for toxicological analysis. This is because the kidneys are essential for filtering toxins from the blood and can accumulate poisons, making them a valuable organ to analyze in cases of suspected poisoning.

For toxicological analysis, various samples and organs should be preserved to identify poisoning or drug use.

  • Blood: Collect venous blood (preferably from femoral, iliac, or axillary veins) in a tube with lithium heparin or EDTA, or fluoride/oxalate if alcohol is suspected.
  • Vomit and Stomach Contents: Place in a clean glass jar or plastic tub with a tight-fitting lid.
  • Feces: For heavy metal poisoning, collect 20-30g of rectal contents in a screw-topped jar or snap-on-lid container.
  • Liver and Other Organs: Liver concentrates many drugs. Half the liver and gallbladder should be placed in a clean container. Bile may also be required for certain drug analyses (e.g., chlorpromazine, morphine).
  • Hair and Nail Clippings: For heavy metal poisoning (e.g., arsenic, lead), collect hair pulled at the roots and nail clippings. These metals are detectable in keratin.
  • Exhaled Air: Collected as required, with no preservative needed.
  • Scene Residues: Collect relevant materials from the scene, such as tablets or containers, with no preservative.
  • Other Organs and Specimens: Urine, sweat, saliva, spleen, kidneys, brain

Lungs (Option B): Not typically preserved unless the poisoning involves inhaled toxins.

Muscle (Option C): Not usually preserved unless there’s a specific reason, such as muscle breakdown from certain toxins.

Heart (Option D): Preserved only if there’s suspicion of cardiac involvement in the poisoning, but not a primary focus in most cases.

questions.text: What is the first postmortem change that occurs in a dead body?

choices.text: Greenish discoloration of right iliac fossa

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Greenish discoloration of right iliac fossa

Explanation:

  • Greenish discoloration of the right iliac fossa is the first postmortem change that happens, typically within 24–48 hours after death. It results from the breakdown of red blood cells and the release of hemoglobin, which reacts with the tissue and gives a greenish hue. The right iliac fossa is where the large intestine is located, and the green discoloration indicates the onset of decomposition, particularly the production of hydrogen sulfide by bacteria in the intestines.

Decomposition:

  • Decomposition is the biological process by which organic substances break down into simpler matter, critical for recycling nutrients in ecosystems.
  • It occurs through two main mechanisms: Autolysis and Putrefaction.

Autolysis

Putrefaction

Autolysis is the self-digestion of tissues caused by the body’s own enzymes after death.

 

Characteristics of Autolysis:

  • Initiation: Begins immediately after death when metabolic processes cease.
  • Mechanism: Enzymatic action leads to cell lysis, altering tissue appearance and texture.

Examples of Autolytic Changes:

  • Clouding of the Cornea: The first observable external change, losing transparency due to cellular breakdown.
  • Changes in Brain Glandular Tissue: The first internal change, where neuronal and glial cells undergo lysis.

Note:

Aseptic Autolysis: Occurs in intrauterine fetal demise, leading to mummification without bacterial involvement.

Putrefaction is driven by bacterial activity, resulting in tissue breakdown and gas production.

Characteristics of Putrefaction:

  • Bacterial Involvement: Primarily caused by Clostridium perfringens.
  • Lytic Enzyme: The main enzyme involved is lecithinase, which breaks down cell membranes.

Stages of Putrefaction:

  1. Color Change:
    • The first internal change is reddish-brown discoloration of the aortic intima.
    • The first external change is green discoloration in the right iliac fossa due to the breakdown of hemoglobin.
  2. Mechanism of Color Change:
    • Hydrogen Sulfide Production: Bacteria produce hydrogen sulfide, which forms a green compound with hemoglobin.
    • The cecum is the primary site of discoloration due to high bacterial activity.
  3. Gas Formation:
    • Gas production leads to bloating, with gases like carbon dioxide, methane, and hydrogen sulfide.
  4. Liquefaction of Tissue:
    • Tissues become liquefied, losing structural integrity, contributing to the characteristic odor of decomposition.
  5. Timing of Discoloration:
    • Discoloration begins within 12-18 hours in summer and 1-2 days in winter, influenced by temperature and bacterial activity.

Incorrect Options:

Maggot formation (Option A) occurs during the later stages of decomposition. Maggot infestation usually begins a few hours after death, but it's not the first change that happens in the body. This is a sign of decomposition, but it does not occur immediately after death.

Putrefaction (Option B) is the process of decay caused by bacterial action, which begins a few hours after death. It leads to the breakdown of tissues and release of gases, causing bloating and a foul smell. While putrefaction is a significant postmortem change, it is not the first to occur.

Mummification (Option D) occurs in specific environmental conditions, such as very dry climates, and involves the preservation of the body due to dehydration. It happens much later in the decomposition process and is not the first change after death.

questions.text: Identify the postmortem change given in the following image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Marbling

 

Explanation

  • Marbling is a postmortem change characterized by a branching, vein-like pattern on the skin due to the breakdown of hemoglobin and bacterial proliferation (e.g., Clostridium welchii) within blood vessels.
  • The discoloration results from the conversion of hemoglobin to sulfhemoglobin, producing a greenish-black appearance.
  • Starts at 24 hours, visible between 36-48 hours.
  • Helps in determining time since death.


 

Tattooing (Option B):

  • Tattooing refers to the deposition of gunpowder particles on the skin during close-range firearm discharge.
  • It appears as punctate abrasions and is unrelated to postmortem decomposition.

Lividity (Option C):

  • Lividity, or postmortem hypostasis, is the pooling of blood in dependent areas of the body after death.
  • It results in a purplish-red discoloration, but it lacks the branching pattern seen in marbling.

Filigree burns (Option D):

  • Filigree burns occur when an electrical current flows through the skin, creating a pattern that resembles lace or a branching network.
  • It is a premortem finding, not a decomposition change.


 

Learning Objective:

 

Putrefaction

  • Stimulated by bacterial activity (primarily Clostridium welchii or Clostridium perfringens).
  • Three stages of change:
    • Color change .
    • Gas formation (producing bloating and distention).
    • Liquefaction of tissues (softening and breakdown of tissues).
  • Color changes:
    • Green discoloration in the right iliac fossa due to hydrogen sulfide produced by bacteria.
    • Starts in 12-18 hours in summer and 1-2 days in winter.
  • Putrefaction sequence:
    • Non-gravid uterus is the last organ to decompose in females.
    • Prostrate is the last organ to decompose in males.

  • Factors inhibiting Putrefaction ( Mnemonic CMS ):
    • Strychinine
    • Metallic poison ( Arsenic,Antimony,Thallium )
    • CO , Cyanide & Carbolic acid.

 

Post-mortem luminescence:

  • Emission of light from the body due to bacterial or fungal activity (e.g., Photobacteria and Armillaria).

questions.text: All of the following changes occur in chronic starvation except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Hyperthermia

Chronic Starvation causes the development of the following changes:

  • Loss of well-being, hunger, and hunger pains.
  • Mental and physical lethargy and easy fatigue.
  • Progressive loss of weight which is rapid in the first six months.
  • Polyuria
  • Increasing wasting, the body weight is reduced by about 40% of the normal.
  • Pigmentation and anaemia
  • Hypothermia and not Hyperthermia; peripheral vascular stasis in cold and hypotension
  • Extreme lethargy, gross mental retardation and loss of self-respect
  • Oedema, first in the feet and lower limbs
  • Reduced resistance to infection causing diarrhoea, dysentery, tuberculosis, etc.

questions.text: A body brought for autopsy is cold and has developed rigor mortis in all 4 limbs and livor mortis at the back/fixed, but no signs of putrefaction. What will be the estimated time since death?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 12–24 hours

 

Explanation:

 

The postmortem interval (PMI) estimation is based on a combination of algor mortis, rigor mortis, livor mortis, and putrefaction findings:

Findings in This Case:

Observation Interpretation
Body cold to touch Suggests death occurred more than 8–12 hours ago (body cools gradually)
Rigor mortis in all four limbs Fully established rigor occurs around 12 hours post-death and lasts up to 24 hrs
Livor mortis fixed at the back Lividity becomes fixed after 6–12 hours
No signs of putrefaction Putrefaction usually begins after 24–36 hours, depending on environment

Given that:

  • Rigor mortis is fully developed (12 hours),

  • Livor mortis is fixed (~8–12 hours),

  • No putrefaction is seen (<24–36 hours),

The most accurate estimate for time since death is 12–24 hours.


 

Livor Mortis

Feature Details
Other names Cadaveric lividity, postmortem staining, suggillations, vibices, "darkening of death"
Site Superficial dermis (capillaries and venules)
Mechanism Gravitational settling of deoxygenated blood → purple-blue skin discolouration in dependent areas
Onset Begins in 30 minutes – 1 hour after death
Fully developed by ~4 hours
Fixation time Becomes fixed in 6–12 hours
Confirmation of fixation Apply pressure → if colour does not blanch, it is fixed
Primary lividity Max intensity seen by 6–12 hours
Secondary lividity Lividity may shift if the body is moved within a few hours of death
Duration Persists until putrefaction begins
Image

The progression of rigor mortis can be divided into three main phases.

 

Phase Description Timeframe
Primary Relaxation Muscles are flaccid; ATP levels are 100%. Sphincters relax, leading to the release of urine/feces. 0–1 hour after death
Rigor Mortis Onset Begins as ATP falls to 85%; actin-myosin cross-linking causes stiffening. Appears in smaller muscles first (eyelids, jaw), progresses to limbs. Begins 1–2 hrs; full by 12 hrs
Rigor Resolution Due to proteolysis, rigidity dissipates. Rigor fades by 24–36 hours depending on conditions. 12–36 hours after death

 

Position Lividity Location
Supine Back of head, neck, trunk, and limbs (excluding pressure areas)
Prone Chest, face, front of limbs
Side Dependent side
Head-down Face and neck blackened
Vertical suspension Legs, hands, external genitalia (glove and stocking pattern)
Drowning Face, chest, hands, feet, calves

Conditions Where Livor Mortis May Be Absent:

  • Severe anaemia

  • Massive blood loss

  • Cachexia (wasting diseases)

  • Some infections like lobar pneumonia

Medicolegal Significance of Livor Mortis:

  • Helps estimate time since death

  • Indicates body position at death

  • Suggests if the body was moved postmortem

  • May hint at cause of death (e.g., cherry-red lividity in CO poisoning)

questions.text: In medicolegal examination accused 18 year old male claims he is 16 year old. Which joint x-ray should be done?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Knee and wrist:

Knee and wrist X-rays are commonly used to assess skeletal maturity and bone age in medico-legal examinations. These joints are particularly useful for evaluating the maturity of the bones and growth plates, which helps in estimating the chronological age of an individual. The epiphyseal ossification patterns in the knee and wrist are well-documented and reliable indicators of skeletal age.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Head & shoulder:

X-rays of the head and shoulder are less useful for determining bone age because the skeletal maturity indicators are less distinct in these regions compared to the knee and wrist.

Option B - Elbow and ankle:

While the elbow and ankle can provide some information on bone age, they are not as commonly used or as reliable as the knee and wrist for this purpose. The elbow and ankle are not as definitive in assessing the maturity of growth plates.

Option D - Elbow & hip:

The elbow and hip can be used to assess bone age, but they are not as commonly employed as the knee and wrist. The hip is less frequently used for this purpose because of variability in ossification patterns.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding adipocere formation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Preservation by saponification:

Adipocere formation, also known as "grave wax," is a process where body fat turns into a waxy substance due to saponification. This process involves the hydrolysis of fats in the body by bacteria, leading to the formation of a soapy, wax-like substance that helps in the preservation of the body.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - High temperature needed:

Adipocere formation generally occurs in a cool, moist environment. High temperatures are not conducive to this process; rather, the process is enhanced in cooler conditions which slow down decomposition and support the saponification process.

Option C - Cool and dry climate needed:

While a cool climate can favor adipocere formation, a dry climate is not ideal. Adipocere formation requires moisture to facilitate the saponification process. Therefore, a cool and moist environment is more conducive to adipocere formation.

Option D - Occurs within minutes to hours:

Adipocere formation is a relatively slow process that can take several weeks to months to develop fully, not minutes to hours.

questions.text: Which of the following eye signs can be appreciated in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Tache Noire

Explanation:

Tache noire sclérotique is seen in the given image. It appears as a triangular area of cell debris and mucus, with color changes from yellow to brown or black after 3 to 6 hours of death.

 

Postmortem Changes in Eye:

  • Medicolegal Importance: Changes in the retina and vitreous humor are more significant for estimating the time since death.

 

Part of Eye

Features

Time Since Death (TSD)

Retina (Option B)
  • Kevorkian Sign: Fragmentation or segmentation of blood column in retinal vessels (cattle trucking or shunting)
  • Occurs within minutes and lasts about an hour.
  • Seen using an opthalmoscope.

Few minutes

Vitreous Humor (Option D)
  • Vitreous humor’s accessibility and resistance to putrefaction make it ideal for forensic analysis.
  • Potassium along with hypoxanthine increases due to autolysis of choroid and retinal cells.
  • Potassium levels provide accurate TSD estimates, unaffected by external factors.
  • The Sturner and Gantner formula is used to estimate TSD from potassium levels.

-

Sclera (Option A)
  • Tache Noire: Appears as two yellow triangles on the sclera (base on limbus, apex at medial or lateral canthus), which darken to brown and then black.
  • Caused by desiccation and deposition of cellular debris, mucus, and dust on exposed conjunctiva and the sclera underneath.
  • Forms if eyelids remain open for 3-4 hours postmortem.

3 - 4 hours

Cornea (Option C)
  • Cornea becomes hazy within 2 hours of death due to drying and dust deposition.
  • Delayed for about 2 hours if lids are closed after death.
  • Transient haziness can be removed by applying water, but permanent opacity occurs after 10-12 hours due to decomposition.

Within 2 hours

Eyeball

  • Eyes appear sunken and become softer within minutes due to reduced intraocular tension.
  • Intraocular pressure drops from 10-22 mmHg during life to zero within 2 hours.

Within 2 hours (IOP becomes zero)

questions.text: Cadaveric spasm is seen in death due to all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Traumatic asphyxia

Explanation:

  • Traumatic asphyxia typically results from external compression of the chest, leading to venous congestion and petechial hemorrhages. It does not typically cause cadaveric spasm as the mechanism of death is slower compared to the instantaneous deaths associated with cadaveric spasm.

Incorrect Options:

Suicidal gun-shot wound (Option A): Cadaveric spasm can occur in individuals who commit suicide by gunshot, particularly if they were holding the weapon at the time of death. The intense emotional state and instantaneous death may lead to this phenomenon.

Electrocution (Option B): Cadaveric spasm is often observed in electrocution cases due to the immediate and intense contraction of muscles caused by the electric current and tight grasping of electric wire.

Drowning (Option C): In cases of drowning, cadaveric spasm may involve the hands tightly clutching weeds, mud, or other objects in the water, indicating a struggle before death.

questions.text: A 42-year-old HIV-positive patient died, and his body was brought for post-mortem. The method of autopsy to be done is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Rokitansky technique

Explanation:

Methods of Autopsy

1. Virchow’s Method (M/C)

  • One-by-one organ removal. (Option C ruled out)
  • Fast and easy.
  • Typically used for general autopsies.

2. Ghon’s/en-Block Method

  • Targeted organ removal (Cervical, Thoracic, Abdominal, Pelvic blocks). (Option A ruled out)
  • Organ relations remain intact.
  • Thoracic block for chest-related issues, pelvic block for sexual assaults.
  • Useful when preserving inter-organ relationships.

3. Lettule’s/en-Masses/Evisceration (Option B ruled out)

  • Large masses of organs removed together (C+T+A+P).
  • Complete viscera removal.
  • Blood vessels and vascular supply intact.
  • Suitable for minor bleeding cases.

4. Rokitansky/In-situ Method (Option D)

  • Inside dissection.
  • Used in infectious diseases (HIV, Hepatitis, COVID-19).
  • Highly transmissible diseases.
  • Also used for infants <1 year to minimize contamination risk.

questions.text: Study of death in all aspects is known as:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Thanatology

  • Thanatology deals with death in all aspects including somatic, systemic and clinical, and molecular or cellular death.

Thanatology:

  • Death and Dying: Examining the biological, physiological, and medical aspects of death, as well as the experiences, emotions, and psychological processes associated with dying.
  • Bereavement and Grief: Investigating the psychological, emotional, and social responses to the loss of a loved one, including theories of grief, coping mechanisms, and support for individuals experiencing bereavement.
  • End-of-Life Care: Exploring the ethical, legal, and practical considerations surrounding palliative care, hospice care, advance care planning, and the management of pain and symptoms in individuals nearing the end of life.
  • Cultural and Religious Perspectives: Investigating how different cultures, religions, and belief systems understand and approach death, funeral rituals, mourning practices, and concepts of afterlife or spiritual continuity.
  • Social and Legal Aspects: Examining the societal and legal frameworks surrounding death, including issues such as euthanasia, assisted suicide, funeral industry practices, organ donation, and legal rights and responsibilities related to death and dying.

Forensic anthropology (Option B): Forensic anthropology involves the study of human remains. It involves applying the skeletal analysis, descriptive data, body marks, and photographs of the individual together to get to forensic inferences.

Toxicology (Option C): Toxicology is the study of analysing suspect samples for the presence of toxins. It only deals with toxins that can be a cause of death- one aspect of death and not all of them.

Molecular death (Option D): Molecular death is the death of cells and tissues individually. It occurs one to two hours after the stoppage of the vital functions.

questions.text: Post-mortem examination of a dead body reveals contraction of the hands with absent primary relaxation. What is this suggestive of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Cadaveric spasm

  • Cadaveric spasm (instantaneous rigor) is a rare postmortem phenomenon where the muscles stiffen immediately at the time of death without passing through the usual phase of primary muscular relaxation seen in typical rigor mortis.

Key Features:

  • Immediate onset: Occurs at the moment of death.
  • Muscle groups affected: Usually involves small muscle groups, especially the hands and fingers.
  • Violent deaths: Often associated with sudden, traumatic, or violent deaths.
  • Emotional stress: Common in situations involving intense nervous tension before death, like drowning, suicides, or combat situations.
  • Clenched fist: A classic sign, often seen when the deceased was holding an object firmly at death (e.g., weapon or grass in homicide).

Rigor mortis (Option A): Involves a gradual stiffening of muscles, typically starting 2-6 hours after death, with a period of primary relaxation beforehand.

Livor mortis (Option B): Postmortem lividity, where blood settles due to gravity, causing purple discoloration.

Algor mortis (Option D): Is the cooling of the body after death.

questions.text: The temperature of the body of a deceased person is found to be 39°C. Which of the following is the most probable reason?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Septicemia

Explanation

  • Septicemia, which is a systemic infection with widespread inflammation, is a common cause of fever in both living and deceased individuals.
  • It can cause hyperthermia due to the body's inflammatory response.
  • Elevated body temperature within the first two hours after death points toward a diagnosis of Postmortem caloricity.
    • Postmortem Caloricity:
      • Refers to the condition where the body temperature remains elevated for the first two hours after death.
      • Causes of Postmortem Caloricity:

1. Disturbed heat regulation

2. Increased heat production (excessive muscle contraction)

3. Excessive bacterial activity
  • Sunstroke
  • Pontine hemorrhage
  • Tetanus
  • Strychnine poisoning
  • Septicaemia
  • Cholera

Note: Burns do not typically cause postmortem caloricity.

Incorrect Options:

Cyanide poisoning (Option A): Cyanide poisoning typically causes rapid death and may lead to hypothermia rather than fever. Cyanide inhibits cellular respiration, leading to metabolic acidosis, but does not usually result in a fever like septicemia.

Corrosive poisoning (Option C): Corrosive poisoning (e.g., acid or alkali ingestion) can cause significant damage to tissues, but it does not typically result in a high body temperature like 39°C. It might lead to shock and other complications, but fever is not the hallmark sign.

Intra-abdominal hemorrhage (Option D): Intra-abdominal hemorrhage typically results in hypovolemic shock due to blood loss, leading to low body temperature (hypothermia) rather than fever.

questions.text: The method of autopsy carried out en masse to remove from the tongue to the prostate is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Letulle technique

Explanation

  • Letulle technique is named after Maurice Letulle which involves the removal of organs together in one mass from tongue to prostate

Methods of Autopsy

1. Virchow’s Method (M/C)

  • One-by-one organ removal. (Option A ruled out)
  • Fast and easy.
  • Typically used for general autopsies.

2. Ghon’s/en-Block Method

  • Targeted organ removal (Cervical, Thoracic, Abdominal, Pelvic blocks). (Option C ruled out)
  • Organ relations remain intact.
  • Thoracic block for chest-related issues, pelvic block for sexual assaults.
  • Useful when preserving inter-organ relationships.

3. Lettule’s/en-Masses/Evisceration (Option D)

  • Large masses of organs removed together (C+T+A+P).
  • Complete viscera removal.
  • Blood vessels and vascular supply intact.
  • Suitable for minor bleeding cases.

4. Rokitansky/In-situ Method (Option B ruled out)

  • Inside dissection.
  • Used in infectious diseases (HIV, Hepatitis, COVID-19).
  • Highly transmissible diseases.
  • Also used for infants <1 year to minimize contamination risk.

questions.text: From the dense vegetation near the highway, the police have found the remains of a burnt body. The location was discovered with the help of a sniffer dog, as they were tracing a 25-year-old IT worker who had gone missing the night before. To determine the identity of the victim, the team needs to gather a suitable sample. Which type of tissue from a charred body is most effective for identification purposes?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Teeth:

  •  The best tissue for identification purposes is the teeth (Option C)

  • Teeth are highly durable and resistant to heat, making them more likely to survive the burning process compared to other tissues.

  • Dental records, including dental charts, X-rays, and dental impressions, can be used to compare with the teeth recovered from the burnt body to establish a positive identification.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hair: While hair can provide some information for identification, it is more susceptible to damage by fire and may not be as reliable as teeth.

Option B - Bone:  Bone can also provide information for identification, but it may be severely damaged or fragmented in cases of extensive burning.

Option D - Blood: Blood is not a suitable tissue for identification purposes in a burnt body, as it would likely be destroyed during the burning process.

questions.text: Paradoxical undressing is seen in :
questions.solution:
Correct Ans: C

  • Paradoxical undressing is a phenomenon that can occur in cases of severe hypothermia.
  • When a person is experiencing extreme cold and their core body temperature drops significantly, paradoxical undressing refers to the behaviour of the individual inexplicably removing their clothing, often resulting in being found partially or completely naked.
  • Peripheral vasoconstriction caused by cold temperatures may also contribute to discomfort, leading to clothing removal.

Incorrect option: 

Option A. Heart stress: Heart stress, also known as cardiac stress or cardiac strain, refers to excessive strain or demand placed on the heart. It is not associated with paradoxical undressing.

Option B. Voyeurism: Voyeurism is a paraphilic disorder characterized by deriving sexual pleasure from observing others without their consent. It is unrelated to paradoxical undressing.

Option D. LSD overdose: LSD (Lysergic acid diethylamide) is a hallucinogenic drug, and an overdose of LSD can lead to various physiological and psychological effects. However, paradoxical undressing is not a recognized symptom or consequence of LSD overdose.

questions.text: Identify the following post mortem change:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Suggillation:

  • Suggillation, also known as livor mortis or postmortem lividity, refers to the discoloration of the skin that occurs after death. It happens as a result of the settling of blood in the dependent parts of the body, due to the gravitational pull. This pooling of blood gives a reddish or purplish discoloration to the skin, which can be observed in the areas closest to the ground or pressure points as seen in the given image.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Tattooing: Tattooing is not a postmortem change but rather a deliberate process of injecting ink into the skin during a person's lifetime to create permanent designs or patterns.

Option C - Putrefaction: Putrefaction refers to the process of decomposition of body tissues after death. It involves the breakdown of proteins by bacteria and enzymes, leading to the release of foul-smelling gases, bloating of the body, and eventual disintegration. While putrefaction is a postmortem change, it is not the correct answer in this context.

Option D - Decomposition: Decomposition refers to the process by which organic matter breaks down into simpler substances after death. It involves various physical, chemical, and biological changes, including putrefaction, autolysis (self-digestion of cells), and skeletonization. While decomposition is a general term for the overall process of breakdown, it is not the specific answer related to the given context.

questions.text: Which of the following trait is feature of the female skull ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Mandible Rounded:

  • Mandible Rounded in female and Mandible is squared in male

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Larger teeth: The size of teeth is not a distinguishing feature between male and female skulls. Tooth size can vary among individuals, but it is not directly related to sexual dimorphism.

Option B - Mastoid medium-large: Mastoid medium-large in male, in females it is small.

Option D - Zygomatic is more pronounced: Zygomatic is more pronounced in male and it is less pronounced in female.

Identify the correct pair:


	
		
			i. Mummification
			
			1)

			2)

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - i -3, ii-4, iii-1, iv-2:

  • Mummification: Mummification is the preservation of a dead body, typically achieved through the removal of moisture and the use of chemicals, natural processes, or environmental conditions. It involves drying out the body to prevent decomposition. Therefore, it is correctly paired with option 3.

  • Adipocere: Adipocere, also known as "grave wax," is a waxy substance that forms on a corpse under specific conditions, such as when the body is buried in a moist environment or submerged in water. It is a result of the hydrolysis of fats in the body. Thus, it is correctly paired with option 4.

  • Marbling: Marbling, in the context of death, refers to the discoloration or mottling of the skin after death. It occurs due to the settling of blood and the pooling of blood in the lower parts of the body. Therefore, it is correctly paired with option 1.

  • Lividity of death: Lividity of death, also known as livor mortis, is the process by which blood settles in the lower parts of the body after death, resulting in a purple or reddish discoloration of the skin. It occurs due to the gravitational pull on the blood. Thus, it is correctly paired with option 2.

  • Therefore, the correct pair is:
    • i - Mummification (3)
    • ii - Adipocere (4)
    • iii - Marbling (1)
    • iv - Lividity of death (2)

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, B and C are incorrect as they do not match the correct pairings

questions.text: A girl was allegedly kidnapped by a man. In court, she says that she is a major and is married to the man, X ray images of her elbow, wrist and pelvis are given. What is the approximate age of the girl?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 21 to 22 years:

Explanation:

  • A method called skeletal age assessment can be used to determine an individual's approximate age based on X-ray images of their elbow, wrist, and pelvis. This method relies on assessing ossification centers and fusion of growth plates in these areas, which occur at predictable ages during development. The X-ray findings are consistent with the girl’s age of 21-22.

  • Findings:

    • Elbow: In a 21-22 year old female, the epiphyseal plates in the elbow region should be closed, indicating the completion of growth and fusion. The bones of the elbow joint, including the humerus, radius, and ulna, should appear fully developed and fused. The joint space should be minimal, and the bony contours should be well-defined.

    • Wrist: At this age, the growth plates in the wrist region should also be closed, indicating the completion of growth. The carpal bones of the wrist, including the scaphoid, lunate, triquetrum, pisiform, trapezium, trapezoid, capitate, and hamate, should be well-formed and have fused together. The bony architecture of the wrist should be well-defined.

    • Pelvis: In a 21-22 year old female, the pelvis should have completed its growth and reached its adult form. The ilium, ischium, and pubis bones of the pelvis should be fully developed and fused. The sacroiliac joints should be stable, and the symphysis pubis should be fused with minimal or no joint space.

Bone Region Epiphyseal Fusion Age (approximate)
Wrist (Lower end of radius & ulna) 17–18 years
Elbow (medial epicondyle, lateral epicondyle, capitulum, etc.) 14–16 years
Pelvis (iliac crest, ischial tuberosity) 18–21 years
Clavicle (medial end) 21–22 years (last to fuse)

questions.text: Identify the post-mortem change described below.:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Suggilation:

  • Suggillation, also known as livor mortis or lividity, refers to the discoloration of the skin that occurs after death due to the settling of blood in the dependent areas of the body.

  • This happens because, after death, blood circulation ceases, and gravity causes blood to pool in the lowest parts of the body.

  • This results in a purplish-red or bluish discoloration of the skin in those areas.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Tattooing: Tattooing refers to the permanent insertion of ink or pigment into the dermis layer of the skin. It is not a post-mortem change but rather a deliberate form of body modification performed during a person's lifetime.

Option C - Putrefaction: Putrefaction is the process of decomposition of organic matter after death. It involves the breakdown of tissues by bacteria and other microorganisms, leading to the release of foul-smelling gases and the decay of body tissues. While putrefaction is a post-mortem change, it is not the correct option in this case.

Option D - Decomposition: Decomposition refers to the process by which organic substances break down into simpler forms. It includes various chemical and physical changes that occur after death, such as the breakdown of proteins, fats, and carbohydrates. Putrefaction is one of the stages of decomposition. While decomposition is a general term for post-mortem changes, it is not the specific term used to describe the discoloration of the skin seen in suggillation.

questions.text: What is the first postmortem change that occurs in a dead body?

choices.text: Greenish discoloration of right iliac fossa

questions.solution:
Correct Options C -Greenish discoloration of right iliac fossa:

  • Greenish discoloration of the right iliac fossa, known as the Greenish Line of Hochenegg, is one of the early signs of decomposition and is observed before  any other changes such as maggot formation, putrefaction, or mummification.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Maggot formation: Maggot formation occurs during the later stages of decomposition, after the initial discoloration of the right iliac fossa.

Option B - Putrefaction: Putrefaction, the breakdown of body tissues, occurs after the initial discoloration.

Option D - Mummification: Mummification is a specific form of postmortem preservation and does not occur as the first change in a dead body.

questions.text: The most reliable criteria among Gustafson's criteria for age estimation is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Translucency of root:

  • Teeth play a crucial role in the identification of individuals, especially in forensic odontology. Gustafson's technique, developed by Gustafson in 1950, is a widely used method for age estimation in adults based on dental characteristics.

  • Among Gustafson's criteria, the most reliable criterion for age estimation is the translucency of the root (Option C).

  • The technique involves attributing scores for various age-related changes observed in teeth, such as attrition, periodontal ligament retractions, secondary dentin formations, root translucency, and root resorption.

  • The translucency of the root is considered one of the most reliable indicators of age, as it gradually increases with age due to the deposition of secondary dentin and changes in the root structure.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B & D - Root resorption, Paradentosis & Attrition:

  • While these criteria are also considered in Gustafson's technique, the translucency of the root is considered the most reliable indicator of age estimation among Gustafson's criteria.

questions.text:
Which option is correct regarding techniques of organ removal during autopsy :

A. Rockitansky – In situ

B. Virchow – en masse

C. Ghon’s – en block

D. Letulle – One by one

choices.text: A, B and C are correct
B and D, A are correct
A, B, C and D are correct

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - A and C:

  • Rockitansky – In situ: This technique refers to the removal of organs one by one while keeping them in their original position within the body. It allows for a more detailed examination and dissection of each organ individually. eg. in cases of HIV, Hep B etc.
  • Ghon's – en block: Ghon's technique involves the removal of multiple organs as a single unit or block.
  • This technique is commonly used in organ transplantation procedures to preserve the integrity of the organs and minimize ischemic time.
  • Organs removed as organ blocks and subsequently dissected

Incorrect Option:

Option B - A, B, and C are correct:

  • Rockitansky – In situ: Explained above.
  • B is incorrect – Virchows – One by One: Technique, also known as the "one by one" technique, is a method used in autopsies. hence does not match as written above.
  • Ghon's – en block: Explained above.

Option C - B and D, A are correct:

  • Virchows – One by one: Technique, also known as the "one by one" technique, is a method used in autopsies. It involves the sequential removal of organs for examination and analysis, allowing for a systematic and thorough assessment of each organ individually.
  • Letulle method, also known as “en masse”. In this method, the entire organ block is removed as one. hence does not match as written above.

Option D - A, B, C and D are correct:

  • B and D both are incorrect

questions.text: Which option provides the most accurate description of a posthumous child?

Incorrect Options:

questions.text: What is the odor of the mummified body?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Odorless

  • Mummification is a process characterized by the rapid dehydration and desiccation of a dead body, resulting in the preservation of its natural appearances and features through evaporation of water. Here are the key points about mummification:

    • Definition: Rapid dehydration and desiccation of the body, preserving its natural appearance.

    • Modification of putrefaction: Mummification is a form of dry decomposition, distinct from the wet decomposition seen in putrefaction.

    • Physical changes: The entire body loses weight, becomes thin, stiff, and brittle. It also becomes odorless.

    • Prevention of decomposition: The process of normal decomposition, which involves the growth of microorganisms, is prevented or significantly retarded in mummification. This is due to the rapid dehydration and lack of moisture, which inhibits microbial growth.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Pungent: This option is not correct. A pungent odor refers to a strong, sharp, and often unpleasant smell. It is not typically associated with a mummified body, as the process of mummification involves the preservation of the body and the prevention of decomposition.

Option C - Putrid: This option is not correct. The term "putrid" refers to a foul or rotten smell associated with decomposition. A mummified body does not have a putrid odor because the mummification process hinders decomposition.

Option D - Offensive: This option is not correct. An offensive odor refers to a strong, unpleasant, and offensive smell. Similar to the previous options, a mummified body does not have an offensive odor due to the preservation process that prevents decomposition.

questions.text: Which is the first organ to putrefy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Brain:

  • When it comes to decomposition or putrefaction of the body after death, the brain is generally the first organ to undergo significant decomposition.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Heart: Heart may undergo changes after death, such as loss of contractility and blood circulation, it does not typically decompose as rapidly as the brain.

Option C - Kidney: Kidneys can be affected by postmortem changes, they generally do not decompose as quickly as the brain.

Option D - Prostate: Prostate may undergo changes after death, but it does not decompose as rapidly as the brain.

questions.text: Which of the following is commonly used for preservation of viscera in toxicology autopsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Saturated salt solution:

  • Saturated salt solution is commonly used for the preservation of viscera in toxicology autopsy. It is a hypertonic solution that helps to prevent decomposition and maintain the integrity of the tissues for further toxicological analysis. The high salt concentration creates an osmotic environment that inhibits bacterial growth and enzymatic degradation.

  • Various methods of preserving viscera:

    1. Saturated salt solution

    2. Formalin fixation

    3. Freezing

    4. Alcohol preservation

    5. Formaldehyde solution

    6. Formalin-alcohol solution

    7. Frozen section

    8. Liquid nitrogen

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Glycerin: Glycerin is not commonly used for the preservation of viscera in toxicology autopsy. While it has some preservative properties, it is not as effective as saturated salt solution for maintaining tissue integrity and preventing decomposition.

Option B - Rectified spirit: Rectified spirit, which is a type of alcohol, is not typically used for preservation in toxicology autopsy. It may have some disinfectant properties but is not suitable for long-term tissue preservation.

Option C - Formalin: Formalin is commonly used for general tissue preservation and fixation in anatomical pathology, but it is not specifically preferred for toxicology autopsy. It may affect the results of toxicological analyses and can interfere with certain tests.

questions.text: Rigor mortis occurs first in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Myocardium:

  • Rigor mortis refers to the stiffening of the body's muscles after death due to biochemical changes in muscle tissue.

  • It typically begins within a few hours after death and progresses gradually over the next 6 to 12 hours. 

  • Rigor mortis first appears in the heart muscle within an hour after death.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B & D - Eyelids, Intestines & Neck:

  • Among the voluntary muscles, rigor mortis usually develops sequentially and follows a descending pattern, the so-called Nysten’s law:

    • It first appears in the muscles of the eye lids (orbicularis oculi) (3–5 h), then in jaw, facial muscles (4–5 h), neck, thorax (5–7 h) upper limb (from shoulder to the hand) (7–9 h), abdomen, lower limb (from the hip to the foot) (9–11 h), and lastly in the small muscles of fingers and toes (11–12 h).

questions.text: Identical twins have similarities in all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Fingerprint pattern:

  • Fingerprint patterns are not solely determined by genetic factors but also influenced by other developmental factors during the formation of the ridges and patterns on the fingers. As a result, even identical twins will have distinct fingerprint patterns.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Blood group: Identical twins typically have the same blood group.

Option B - DNA fingerprinting: Identical twins will have virtually identical DNA profiles as they share the same genetic information

Option D - Iris color: Identical twins often have similar iris colors as it is influenced by genetic factors. While there can be slight variations in shade or intensity, the overall color of the iris is usually similar between identical twins.
